choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: An elderly female with mediastinal mass undergoes a microscopic examination showing red cell aplasia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Thymoma

Option B:

The description of an elderly female with a mediastinal mass and microscopic examination showing red cell aplasia is suggestive of a thymoma. Thymomas are tumors arising from the thymic epithelial cells in the thymus, which is located in the mediastinum. Thymomas can be associated with various paraneoplastic syndromes, and one of them is pure red cell aplasia. Direct lines from Robbins. “In addition to myasthenia gravis, thymomas may be associated with several other paraneoplastic syndromes. These include in rough order of frequency, pure red cell aplasia, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi organ autoimmunity”.

Thymoma is a tumor of the thymic epithelial cells and can present as a mediastinal mass. It is associated with several paraneoplastic syndromes including pure red cell aplasia, which leads to severe anemia due to the failure of the bone marrow to produce red blood cells, myasthenia gravis, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi-organ autoimmunity.

Explanation:

Option A. Bronchogenic cancer often presents as a mediastinal mass, especially in smokers. However, it is not commonly associated with red cell aplasia, but rather with other paraneoplastic syndromes such as hypercalcemia (due to production of PTH-related protein) or the secretion of ADH or ACTH.

Option C. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can present as a mediastinal mass. It may cause bone marrow involvement leading to various cytopenias but is not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma typically arises from the epithelial cells of the skin or mucous membranes and is not commonly found within the mediastinum. It is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, but not typically with red cell aplasia.

Educational Objective:

Thymoma is the likely diagnosis in an elderly patient with a mediastinal mass and red cell aplasia, as thymomas are associated with this condition and other paraneoplastic syndromes such as myasthenia gravis, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi-organ autoimmunity.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p493

choices.text: It involves both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14
In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast
Familial type is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene and the other copy is normal

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Knudson's two-hit hypothesis theory on retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Familial type is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait

 

Option C:

 

Retinoblastoma is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.

Knudson's hypothesis, also known as the two-hit hypothesis or multiple-hit hypothesis states that cancer is the result of accumulated mutations in a cell's DNA.
Explanation:

Option A. Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14, are required to produce retinoblastoma.

Option B. In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).

Option D. In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene in the germline (the first hit), and the other copy is normal. Retinoblastoma develops when the normal RB allele is mutated in retinoblasts as a result of a spontaneous somatic mutation (the second hit).

Educational Objective:

Familial retinoblastoma is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, not autosomal recessive. According to Knudson's two-hit hypothesis, a single inherited mutation in one allele of the RB gene is sufficient to predispose to retinoblastoma, but a second somatic mutation in the other allele must occur for the cancer to develop.

questions.text: Match the following genes correctly with their tumors:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • C- myc is associated with Burkitt’s lymphoma (Ref: Robbins…316)
  • PLAG 1 is associated with pleomorphic adenoma (Ref: Robbins…748)
  • N myc is associated with neuroblastoma (Ref: Robbins…289)
  • Rb is associated with retinoblastoma (Ref: Robbins…147)

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 147, 289, 316, 748

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma of colon

 

Option B:

 

Psammoma bodies are not a common feature of colon adenocarcinomas. They are more typically associated with certain other epithelial tumors, like ovarian and thyroid papillary carcinomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid: It is known to frequently have psammoma bodies, which are calcified concentric structures found within the tumor tissue.

 

Option C: Meningioma: This benign brain tumor often contains psammoma bodies, contributing to its classic histological appearance.

 

Option D: Papillary cancer of the ovary (serous cystadenoma of the ovary): Similar to papillary thyroid carcinoma, ovarian papillary tumors can also exhibit psammoma bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies are calcified structures often found in certain neoplasms such as papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, meningioma, papillary cancer of the ovary (serous cystadenoma of the ovary) and occasionally in mesothelioma but are not typically seen in adenocarcinoma of the colon.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1098

questions.text: Match the Immuno- markers with its associated neoplasm:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a
 

Explanation:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 270

questions.text: A physician is considering the differential diagnoses for a patient's elevated serum tumor marker levels. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is known to be elevated in various malignancies and benign conditions. Which of the following conditions is NOT typically associated with an elevated CEA level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoma prostate

Option C:

Prostate specific antigen (PSA) is elevated in carcinoma prostate

Carcinoma of the prostate CEA is not a marker for prostate cancer. Instead, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the commonly used tumor marker for diagnosing and monitoring prostate cancer.

Explanation:

Option A. Alcoholic cirrhosis Alcoholic cirrhosis can lead to elevated CEA levels. CEA is not specific for malignancy and can be raised in a variety of benign liver conditions, including cirrhosis, especially when related to alcohol use.

Option B. Carcinoma of the colon CEA levels are frequently elevated in colorectal cancer and can be used as a marker for monitoring treatment response or disease recurrence after the removal of the primary tumor.

Option D. Emphysema Chronic lung conditions, including emphysema, can also result in elevated CEA levels, even though these are not malignant conditions. Smoking, which is a risk factor for emphysema, can itself cause elevated CEA levels.

Educational Objective:

Carcinoma of the prostate, is not associated with elevated CEA levels. Instead, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the tumor marker commonly elevated in prostate cancer. CEA is used primarily for monitoring colorectal cancer and can be elevated in various benign conditions, including liver and lung diseases.

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 336

choices.text: Mutation of the PTEN gene
Mutation of the CDKN2 gene
Mutation of RB gene
Mutation of the WT gene

questions.text: A 31-year-old female has fecal blood identified during a physical examination. A colonoscopy reveals an ulcerated mass in her proximal rectum. In the past, she was operated and treated for a ductal carcinoma of her left breast and a malignant thyroid tumor. Of the following, what is the most likely mutation if she is diagnosed with Cowden’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mutation of the PTEN gene

 

Option A:

 

Patients with Cowden’s syndrome develop colorectal, thyroid, and breast neoplasms. The underlying mutation is that of PTEN (located on chromosome 10q23)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mutations of CDKN2 are associated with malignant melanoma

 

Option C. RB with retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. WT with Wilms tumor 

 

Educational objective:

 

Patients with Cowdens syndrome have mutation of the PTEN gene.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page:292 table: 7.7

choices.text: Activation of cell cycle arrest

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with persistent abdominal pain and diarrhea. CT scan reveals the presence of a tumor in the pancreas. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the KRAS proto-oncogene. Which of the following best describes the role of KRAS in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Promotion of cell proliferation

Explanation:

KRAS is a proto-oncogene that encodes for a protein involved in cell signaling pathways that regulate cell growth and division. Mutations in KRAS can lead to the activation of these pathways, promoting cell proliferation and survival. KRAS mutations are common in pancreatic adenocarcinoma and are associated with a poorer prognosis

questions.text: A patient with Burkitt lymphoma presents with lethargy, weakness, and oliguria after receiving the first cycle of chemotherapy. Laboratory tests reveal abnormalities consistent with tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). Which of the following laboratory findings is LEAST likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypercalcemia

 

Option D:

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome is associated with Burkitt lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), chronic tumors (CLL) and uncommonly solid tumors.
  • It is associated with hypocalcemia and NOT hypercalcemia.

 

Hypercalcemia is NOT a feature of TLS; rather, hypocalcemia is commonly seen due to the precipitation of calcium with the elevated phosphate released from lysed cells.

 

Explanations

 

Option A. Hyperuricemia is typically seen in TLS due to the increased turnover of nucleic acids from rapid cell lysis, leading to excess production of uric acid.

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia results from the release of potassium, the most abundant intracellular cation, into the bloodstream when cells lyse.

 

Option C. Hyperphosphatemia occurs due to the release of intracellular phosphate into the extracellular fluid during cell lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor lysis syndrome is characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia, but not hypercalcemia; instead, hypocalcemia occurs due to the complexing of calcium with elevated phosphate levels.

choices.text: It is involved in DNA repair
It is a tumor suppressor gene
It is not involved in colon cancer

questions.text: A patient presents with a family history of colon cancer. They undergo genetic testing, which reveals a mutation in the APC gene. Which of the following is true about APC?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a tumor suppressor gene

Option C:

It is a tumor suppressor gene. The APC gene encodes a protein that helps regulate cell division and may prevent cells from growing and dividing too rapidly or in an uncontrolled way. Mutations in the APC gene can lead to unchecked cellular proliferation, predisposing individuals to cancer, particularly colorectal cancer.

Explanation:

Option A.  It is a proto-oncogene. Proto-oncogenes are normal genes that can become oncogenes due to mutations or increased expression. Oncogenes can cause the cells to grow and proliferate excessively. The APC gene, however, functions as a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene.

Option B. It is involved in DNA repair.  While DNA repair mechanisms are essential in the prevention of cancer, the APC gene itself is not primarily involved in DNA repair processes. Its primary function relates to the regulation of cell growth and division.

Option D. It is not involved in colon cancer. This statement is incorrect. The APC gene is implicated in colon cancer, as mutations in this gene are commonly found in both sporadic and hereditary forms of colorectal cancer.

Educational Objective:

APC gene is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in the APC gene lead to a loss of function, resulting in increased cell proliferation and a higher risk for developing colorectal cancer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient notices spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearly arranged nodules in different parts of the body. Which of the following malignancies is not associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bladder carcinoma

Option D:

The given clinical presentation is suggestive of migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) and it is not associated with bladder carcinoma.

While bladder carcinoma can be associated with a hypercoagulable state, it is less commonly linked to Trousseau syndrome compared to the adenocarcinomas of the pancreas, lung, and gastrointestinal or gynecologic malignancies.

Explanation:

Option A. Uterine carcinoma: Uterine carcinoma, particularly when adenocarcinoma, can be associated with Trousseau syndrome due to its propensity to induce a hypercoagulable state, leading to venous thromboembolism.

Option B. Pancreatic carcinoma: Pancreatic carcinoma is strongly associated with Trousseau syndrome. The tumor's release of mucins and procoagulant substances can trigger a hypercoagulable state.

Option C. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Bronchogenic carcinoma, especially adenocarcinoma subtype, is known to produce substances that activate the coagulation system, thus it can be associated with Trousseau syndrome.

Educational Objective:

Bladder carcinoma is not commonly associated with Trousseau syndrome, which is characterized by migratory thrombophlebitis and is often seen with deep-seated adenocarcinomas like those of the pancreas, lung, and other visceral organs.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 329

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine health check-up. She has no complaints and her medical history is unremarkable. She undergoes a Pap smear as part of her cervical cancer screening. The cytology report describes disorganized growth of cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. Which of the following best characterizes the cellular changes seen in this patient's Pap smear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dysplasia

Option B:

Pap smear having disorganised growth of the cells with hyperchromatic nuclei is suggestive of dysplasia. Carcinoma is diagnosed when abnormal mitotic figures are discovered and is called invasive when basement membrane is affected.

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal growth and disorganization of cells, often with variations in size, shape, and orientation. The term is often used when referring to precancerous or potentially premalignant conditions. In a Pap smear, dysplastic cells with hyperchromatic (darkly staining) nuclei suggest a higher likelihood of progressing to cervical cancer, especially if abnormal mitotic figures are present.

Explanation:

Option A. Hypertrophy: Hypertrophy refers to an increase in the size of cells, leading to an increase in the size of the organ. It is usually seen in response to increased demand or stimulation by hormones or growth factors. Unlike hyperplasia, hypertrophy does not involve an increase in the number of cells. An example would be the increase in muscle mass due to exercise.

Option C. Metaplasia: Metaplasia is the reversible change from one type of cell to another due to abnormal stimulus, which can potentially predispose to malignancy if the stimulus persists. A classic example is Barrett’s esophagus, where the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus changes to a columnar epithelium in response to chronic gastric acid exposure.

Option D. Hyperplasia: Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue, which may subsequently increase the size of the organ or tissue. It is a response to a stimulus and is usually a controlled process. Hyperplasia can be a physiological response, such as the proliferation of glandular epithelium of the female breast at puberty or pathologic as seen in endometrial hyperplasia.

Educational Objective:

Dysplasia, is a term used to describe disorganized growth of cells with varying size, shape, and orientation, often with hyperchromatic nuclei, suggestive of a precancerous state.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p719-720

choices.text: EGFR positive in non small cell cancer
Her 2 amplification is seen in most breast cancer
N myc  is a tumor suppressor gene

questions.text: In the context of tumor biology, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) EGFR positive in non small cell cancer

 

Option B:

EGFR positivity is commonly seen in non-small cell lung cancer, particularly adenocarcinoma subtype, and can be a target for specific therapies.

Explanation:

Option A.  BRCA1 is not an oncogene but a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

Option C. Her2 amplification occurs in some breast cancer cases but is not seen in the majority. It is significant because Her2 status can affect treatment options and prognosis.

Option D. N myc is a proto-oncogene, not a tumor suppressor gene. It can become an oncogene when mutated or overexpressed, as seen in some cases of neuroblastoma.

Educational Objective:

BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene, EGFR can be overexpressed in non-small cell lung cancer, Her2 is amplified in a subset of breast cancers, and N myc is a proto-oncogene associated with certain types of cancer (neuroblastoma).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/285, 292

choices.text: Aberrant expression of a receptor tyrosine kinase
An inborn defect in DNA repair

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is referred to a dermatologist for several "suspicious" pigmented lesions on his face and neck. Further history reveals the patient has had problems seeing out of his right eye; he is referred to an ophthalmologist, who diagnoses ocular melanoma. Based on the patient’s symptoms, the diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum is considered. This condition results from?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) An inborn defect in DNA repair

Option B:

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a hereditary DNA defect with a deficiency in the ability to repair ultraviolet (sunlight)-induced thymine dimers. Faulty repair leads to increased sun sensitivity, with a predilection to develop skin lesions and skin cancers on exposed skin, as well as ocular melanomas.

Explanation:

Option A.  Aberrant expression of the gene for a receptor tyrosine kinase, such as the Her-2/neu gene product, can cause breast cancer.

Option C. Chemical carcinogens have highly reactive electrophile groups that directly damage DNA, leading to mutations and eventually cancer.

Option D.  A retrovirus is responsible for the development of T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Educational Objective:

Xeroderma pigmentosum is a condition resulting from a hereditary deficiency in the nucleotide excision repair pathway, leading to an inability to repair UV-induced thymine dimers, with resultant increased skin and ocular malignancies.

questions.text:
Which of the following are oncofetal antigens?

 

  1. Alpha-fetoprotein
  2. Carcinoembryonic antigen
  3. Human chorionic gonadotropin
  4. Placental alkaline phosphatase
  5. Immunoglobulins
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are oncofetal antigens.

 

Alpha-fetoprotein is a valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of the following tumors:

 

  • Primary hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratomas
  • Choriocarcinoma

 

Carcinoembryonic antigen is normally detected in the glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells. It is useful in detection, assessing recurrence, and prognosis of the following tumors:

 

  • Adenocarcinoma of lung
  • Colorectal carcinoma

 

CEA levels >5 g/dL are noted in ascitic fluid associated with malignancy.

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin: Not an oncofetal antigen; it is a placental hormone, elevated in choriocarcinoma, testicular tumors.

 

Placental alkaline phosphatase: A placental enzyme, considered a tumor-associated antigen, but not truly oncofetal.

 

Immunoglobulins: These are normal adult proteins; elevated in plasma cell dyscrasias (e.g., multiple myeloma), but not oncofetal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-fetoprotein and carcinoembryonic antigen are oncofetal antigens, which are expressed during fetal development and re-expressed in certain malignancies, aiding in the diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of these cancers.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 336

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with loss of weight and appetite. On clinical examination, grade IV clubbing is evident. Imaging shows periosteal new bone formation and left knee joint effusion. Which of the following tumors is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bronchogenic carcinoma

Option A:

The given clinical history is suggestive of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. It is commonly associated with bronchogenic carcinoma.

Bronchogenic carcinoma, particularly non-small cell lung cancer, is the most common cause of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, which is characterized by periosteal new bone formation, arthritis of adjacent joints, and clubbing.

Explanation:

Option B. Carcinoma of the pancreas: While patients with pancreatic cancer may develop paraneoplastic syndromes, hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is not typically associated with this type of malignancy.

Option C. Esophageal carcinoma:  Esophageal carcinoma can be associated with paraneoplastic phenomena including clubbing, but it is less commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy compared to bronchogenic carcinoma.

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia: Hematologic malignancies like AML are not commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. Paraneoplastic syndromes are more commonly associated with solid tumors.

Educational Objective:

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is characterized by the following:

  • Periosteal new bone formation, primarily at the distal ends of long bones, metatarsals, metacarpals, and proximal phalanges
  • Arthritis of the adjacent joints
  • Clubbing of the digits

choices.text: Number of positive lymph nodes
Metastatic spread to another organ
Number of mitotic figures per high power-field

questions.text: In reviewing the pathology report for a patient diagnosed with colonic adenocarcinoma, which of the following findings is most indicative of the tumor's grade?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Number of mitotic figures per high power field.
 

Option D:

The grade of a tumor is its degree of histologic differentiation (e.g., well, moderate, or poorly differentiated) and represents a subjective determination by the pathologist as to how closely the tumor resembles the tissue type from which it arose (e.g., in colonic adenocarcinoma, whether the tumor cells appear like normal glandular epithelium). In determining the grade of the tumor, the histologic appearance of the tumor is important, including the number of mitotic figures per high-power field.

The number of mitotic figures per high-power field is an important factor in grading a tumor. It provides information about the proliferative activity of the tumor cells and how undifferentiated the tumor tissue is compared to the normal tissue from which it originated.

Explanation:

Option A. While the number of positive lymph nodes is crucial for staging a tumor under the 'N' category in the TNM classification system, it does not determine the histologic grade of the tumor.

Option B. The size of the tumor is used to determine the 'T' category in the TNM system and contributes to the staging, but not grading, of cancer.

Option C. The presence of metastasis is classified under the 'M' category of the TNM system and, like A and B, is used in staging rather than grading.

Educational Objective:

The grade of a tumor is determined by its histologic differentiation, which includes the assessment of mitotic activity, specifically the number of mitotic figures per high power field, and not by the TNM staging factors such as tumor size, nodal involvement, or metastasis.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 246

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to his family physician because of complaints of blood in his stool and intermittent constipation. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. A colonoscopy is performed, revealing a large adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon. As the tumor was removed, a researcher tested the tumor and identified a mutation of RAS gene. Of the following, what was one mechanism by which the tumor developed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abnormal GTPase activity
Option B:

Mutations in RAS commonly lead to abnormal GTPase activity. Normally, RAS has intrinsic GTPase activity, allowing it to cycle between an active and inactive state. A mutation can cause RAS to remain in an active state, continuously signaling for cell growth and division.

Explanation:

Option A:  While inhibition of apoptosis is a common mechanism in tumorigenesis, mutations in the RAS gene typically do not result in the direct inhibition of apoptotic pathways.

Option C: Abnormal tyrosine kinase activity is often associated with mutations in other proto-oncogenes and is not the primary mechanism of action for RAS mutations.

 Option D:  Up-regulation of cytokine receptor expression is a mechanism that could lead to increased cell signaling for proliferation but is not directly related to RAS mutations.

Educational Objective:

Mutations in the RAS gene lead to abnormal GTPase activity, resulting in uncontrolled cell division and mitogenesis, which can contribute to tumorigenesis, such as in colon adenocarcinoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 286

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a past medical history significant for HIV infection has a CD4 count 120 cells/mm³ . The patient is started on antiretroviral therapy, and further evaluation is planned. All of the following are AIDS defining malignancies except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Melanoma
Option D:

Melanoma, while it can occur in patients with HIV/AIDS, is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. The conditions listed in options A, B, and C are specifically associated with the immunosuppressed state in AIDS and have a direct link with opportunistic infections and the patient's compromised immune system.

Explanation:

Option A:  Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, including primary lymphoma of the brain, is an AIDS-defining malignancy. This can be due to the weakened immune system's inability to control oncogenic viruses like EBV, which is associated with lymphoma.

Option B: Invasive cervical carcinoma is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the association with human papillomavirus (HPV) and the increased risk of this malignancy in individuals with compromised immune systems.

Option C: Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), is commonly seen in patients with AIDS and is one of the most recognizable AIDS-defining malignancies.

Educational Objective:

Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and Kaposi sarcoma are considered AIDS-defining malignancies, which occur with increased frequency in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS due to their immunocompromised state. Melanoma is not part of this category.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 256

choices.text: To reduce the uptake of glucose
To increase its lifespan and become immortal
To make intermediated required for proliferation

questions.text: A researcher is studying the metabolic activity of cancer cells and notes that despite adequate oxygen availability, the cells exhibit an increased rate of glycolysis followed by lactic acid fermentation. What is the primary reason for cancer cells to exhibit this metabolic pathway, known as the Warburg effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To make intermediated required for proliferation

Option D:

  • Warburg effect is aerobic glycolysis. In cancer cells, even in the presence of ample oxygen, there is a high level of glucose uptake (so, option ‘a’ is incorrect) and increased conversion of glucose to lactose via the glycolytic pathway (only 2 ATP generated in place of 36 ATP and so, option ‘c’ is incorrect).
  • Warburg effect enables the synthesis of the macromolecules and organelles that are needed for rapid cell growth.

The correct explanation for the Warburg effect is to provide precursors for the synthesis of macromolecules and organelles necessary for cell division and rapid tumor growth, despite the inefficiency in ATP production.

Explanation:

Option A. The Warburg effect is characterized by an increased uptake of glucose, not a reduction, as cancer cells have high energy demands.

Option B. While the Warburg effect contributes to the cancer cells' survival, it does not directly increase their lifespan or cause immortality. Instead, it supports the high metabolic demands of proliferation.

Option C. The Warburg effect does not enhance ATP production since aerobic glycolysis is less efficient than oxidative phosphorylation, generating only 2 ATP molecules per glucose molecule compared to 36 ATP from oxidative phosphorylation.

Educational Objective:

Warburg effect, or aerobic glycolysis, in cancer cells is an adaptation that allows for the rapid synthesis of the macromolecules and organelles needed for cell growth and division, not for increased ATP production.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 299

choices.text: Telomerase is not active in somatic cells
It's activity is more in Germ cells than non-germ cells
Double stranded breaks is repaired by telomerase

questions.text: Identify the false statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Double stranded breaks is repaired by telomerase

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Telomerase activity is absent in most normal human somatic cells because of the lack of expression of TERT

 

Option B. Telomerase core enzyme is composed of a reverse transcriptase subunit and a non-coding RNA used as a template for elongation.

 

Option C. Germ cells have higher telomerase activity than non germ cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telomerase is not responsible for repairing double-stranded DNA breaks. Its main function is to elongate telomeres, which are the protective ends of chromosomes, using an RNA template that is part of the enzyme.

 

Telomerase: 

 

  • Telomerase is an enzyme that maintains telomere length.
  • Telomeres: special repetitive DNA sequences (TTAGGG repeats in humans) at chromosome ends.
  • Telomeres protect chromosomes from being recognized as broken DNA.
  • With each cell division, telomeres shorten contributes to aging and replicative senescence.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b

 

Explanation:

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition page: 323

questions.text: Match the tumor with their biological carcinogens:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

questions.text: Most common carcinoma associated with inferior vena cava metastasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal cell carcinoma

Option C:

  • Renal cell carcinoma and Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common malignancy to involve inferior vena cava.
  • Bronchogenic carcinoma or malignant lymphoma cause invasion of the superior vena cava

Renal cell carcinoma is known for its propensity to invade the renal vein and subsequently the IVC due to its proximity and direct vascular connections. It is the most common malignancy associated with IVC involvement.

Explanation:

 Option A: Small cell carcinoma of the lung  While lung cancers can invade vascular structures, small cell carcinoma of the lung more commonly involves the superior vena cava (SVC), leading to SVC syndrome, rather than the IVC.

Option B: Gastric adenocarcinoma Gastric adenocarcinoma typically metastasizes to the liver, peritoneum, and lymph nodes. Direct invasion into the IVC is rare with gastric cancers.

Option D: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid :Thyroid cancers, including papillary carcinoma, primarily spread to regional neck lymph nodes and, less commonly, to distant sites. Direct IVC invasion is not characteristic of thyroid carcinomas.

Educational Objective:

Renal cell carcinoma is the carcinoma most commonly associated with metastasis to the inferior vena cava. This type of tumor can grow within the kidney's collecting system and extend into the renal vein and then into the IVC.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman underwent a mastectomy along with axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer 1 year back. Now she has developed swelling in left arm. Physical examination showed firm skin over left arm and doughy underlying soft tissue. Patient had complained of cellulitis in left arm 3 months back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphedema

Option B:

Lymphedema is a common complication following mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection due to the obstruction and disruption of lymphatic drainage. The described findings of firm skin and doughy underlying soft tissue in the left arm are consistent with lymphedema.

Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection leads to obstruction and disruption of lymphatics in axilla giving rise to lymphedema.

Explanation:

Option A: Thrombophlebitis typically presents with inflammation and thrombosis of superficial veins, commonly observed in the lower extremities. It is not typically associated with the described findings in the left arm.

Option C: Vasculitis involves inflammation of blood vessels and can present with a variety of symptoms depending on the vessels affected. However, it is not a common surgical complication following mastectomy with lymph node dissection and is less likely in this clinical scenario.

Option D: Tumor embolization refers to the spread of tumor cells through the bloodstream, leading to embolic occlusion of blood vessels. While tumor emboli can occur, they are typically small and rare and would not manifest with the described findings.

Educational objective:

Lymphedema is a common complication following mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection.

choices.text: Spindle cells
Storiform pattern
Target cells
Antoni A and B pattern

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in schwannnoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antoni A and B pattern

 

Option D:

 

In schwannoma, which is a tumor arising from Schwann cells that myelinate nerve fibers, the characteristic histological features include the Antoni A and Antoni B patterns:

 

  • Antoni A pattern is defined by compact, highly cellular areas where spindle-shaped cells are arranged in a palisading fashion. This creates structures known as Verocay bodies, indicative of a well-organized growth pattern.
  • Antoni B pattern is less cellular and consists of a myxoid or microcystic background with less organized spindle cells. This represents a more haphazard growth pattern and can sometimes be associated with cystic changes within the tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spindle cells are indeed a component of schwannomas but are not specific to them as they can be seen in a variety of other neoplastic and reactive processes.

 

Option B. Storiform pattern, characterized by a cartwheel or mat-like arrangement of cells, is not typical for schwannoma. It's more commonly seen in dermatofibroma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma.

 

Option C. Target cells are a type of red blood cell with a bullseye appearance typically associated with conditions like liver disease or hemoglobinopathies, not schwannomas.

 

Educational objective:

 

Schwannomas are characterized by their distinctive Antoni A and B patterns on histology, which helps distinguish them from other soft tissue tumors. While spindle cells are a feature of schwannomas, the presence of the Antoni A and B patterns is more pathognomonic. Storiform patterns and target cells are associated with different pathologies and are not seen in schwannomas.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1302

choices.text: Meningioma
Hemangioma
Glioma

questions.text: Verocay bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Schwannoma

 

Option D:

 

  • Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively.
  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is common and “nuclear-free zones” that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies. In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Meningiomas may exhibit whorled patterns and psammoma bodies, Verocay bodies are not a feature of meningiomas.

 

Option B: Hemangiomas are benign tumors derived from blood vessels and can occur in various tissues including the skin and internal organs. They do not display Verocay bodies.

 

Option C: Gliomas are tumors arising from glial cells in the central nervous system, including astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and ependymal cells. They do not have Verocay bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verocay bodies are seen in schwannomas and are characterized by palisading nuclei creating nuclear-free zones within the densely cellular Antoni A areas of the tumor.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1302

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hypercalcemia, peptic ulcer disease, and a pituitary mass on imaging. Given these clinical features, which of the following conditions is least likely to be part of the patient's underlying syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior pituitary tumors

 

Option B:

 

  • MEN-1, or Wermer syndrome is characterized by anterior pituitary tumours and not posterior pituitary tumours.
  • MEN-1 syndrome is caused by germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called menin.

 

MEN-1 syndrome involves tumors of the anterior pituitary gland, not the posterior pituitary. Symptoms are typically caused by excess hormone production, like prolactin or growth hormone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Foregut carcinoid - Foregut carcinoids (including those found in the thymus, lung, and stomach) are part of the spectrum of MEN-1 syndrome, although less common compared to other manifestations.

 

Option C: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors - These tumors are a hallmark of MEN-1 and can produce a variety of symptoms depending on the hormone they secrete (e.g., gastrin, insulin).

 

Option D: Parathyroid hyperplasia - Primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid hyperplasia is the most common feature of MEN-1 syndrome, causing hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN-1 syndrome, also known as Wermer syndrome, is characterized by anterior pituitary tumors, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, and parathyroid hyperplasia, but not by tumors of the posterior pituitary.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1129

questions.text: Submucosal neuroma is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MEN II B

 

Option C:

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II B (MEN II B) is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas (which can be submucosal), marfanoid habitus, and intestinal ganglioneuromas. Submucosal neuromas are a characteristic finding in MEN II B and can be seen in the gastrointestinal tract, often leading to symptoms like constipation or diarrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I (MEN I) is a syndrome characterized by the presence of tumors in the parathyroid glands, pancreatic islet cells, and the anterior pituitary gland. Submucosal neuromas are not typically associated with MEN I.

 

Option B: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II A (MEN II A) is a syndrome that includes medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism. It does not typically present with submucosal neuromas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Submucosal neuromas are associated with MEN II B and can contribute to the diagnosis of this syndrome.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1130

questions.text: Homer wright rosettes are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuroblastoma

 

Option A: 

 

Neuroblastoma, a tumor arising from the neural crest cells that make up the sympathetic nervous system, commonly exhibits Homer Wright rosettes. These rosettes are characterized by a circular arrangement of tumor cells around a central area of neurofibrillary material.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Also known as Wilms' tumor, nephroblastoma is a kidney tumor usually found in children. It can show other types of rosette formations, but not typically Homer Wright rosettes.

 

Option C: Hepatoma, or hepatocellular carcinoma, is a liver tumor and does not feature the presence of Homer Wright rosettes. Its pathology is markedly different from that of neuroblastic tumors.

 

Option D: Ependymomas are glial cell tumors that can form rosettes known as perivascular rosettes or ependymal rosettes, which are distinct from Homer Wright rosettes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homer wright rosettes are seen in Neuroblastoma.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 480

choices.text: Cervical carcinoma
Oral carcinoma
Laryngeal papillomatosis.
Anorectal carcinoma

questions.text: All of the following are caused by lethal strains of HPV, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laryngeal papillomatosis

 

Option C.

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11, which are considered low-risk types. While it can cause significant morbidity due to recurrent benign papillomas in the larynx, it is not typically associated with the development of cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: Persistent infection with these high-risk HPV types especially HPV 16, 18, 31 and 33 , can lead to the progression of cervical dysplasia to invasive carcinoma.

 

Option B. Oral carcinoma: HPV infection, especially with types 16 and 18, has been linked to the development of oral and oropharyngeal cancers, particularly in the tonsillar and base of the tongue areas.

 

Option D. Anorectal carcinoma: High-risk HPV types, including 16 and 18, are implicated in the development of anal and anorectal carcinomas. These cancers are more prevalent in individuals with persistent HPV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis is typically caused by the low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11, which are not commonly associated with malignancy. In contrast, high-risk HPV types, particularly 16 and 18, are associated with an increased risk of developing cancers such as cervical carcinoma, oral carcinoma, and anorectal carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Sipple Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperthyroidism

 

Option C:

 

  • Hyperthyroidism is not a feature of MEN 2A.

  • Sipple syndrome = MEN type 2A (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A)

  • It is characterized by the classic triad:
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia or adenoma leading to hyperparathyroidism 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pheochromocytoma is a characteristic feature of MEN 2A and presents as a catecholamine-secreting tumor typically originating in the adrenal medulla.

 

Option B: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor of the thyroid and a principal feature of MEN 2A. It arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland and secretes calcitonin.

 

Option D: Primary hyperparathyroidism is part of the MEN 2A syndrome and is due to hyperplasia or adenoma of the parathyroid glands leading to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Educational Objective:

 

While pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and hyperparathyroidism are part of the Sipple syndrome, hyperthyroidism is not.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1130

choices.text: Metaphase is distinct
Due to contamination with infectious agents
High mitotic rate
Deficient tissue sample

questions.text: The cytogenicity of solid tumors is not easily assessed especially in carcinoma cervix because:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to contamination with infectious agents

 

Option B:

 

Contamination with infectious agents could introduce foreign genetic material, making it challenging to obtain accurate and reliable cytogenetic results.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. While a high mitotic rate is a characteristic of rapidly dividing cancer cells, it doesn't necessarily hinder cytogenetic analysis. In fact, a high mitotic rate is often beneficial for cytogenetic studies as it provides more cells in the dividing phase for analysis.

 

Option D. Deficient tissue sample: A deficient tissue sample may indeed hinder cytogenetic analysis. If the sample is insufficient or of low quality, it may not yield enough viable cells for proper analysis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Deficient tissue sampling like sampling from non-representative areas or the necrotic areas will impair the results in most of the solid tumors but the commonest problem with cancer of the cervix is the high contamination rate. So, option ‘B’ is better than option ‘D’.

choices.text: Caused by HPV
Sexually transmitted
Progresses to malignancy
Occurs in genitalia

questions.text: All are true about condylomata acuminata except which of the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Progresses to malignancy

 

Option C:

 

While HPV infection is associated with certain cancers, particularly cervical cancer, condylomata acuminata themselves are benign and rarely progress to malignancy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Caused by HPV This statement is true. Condylomata acuminata, also known as genital warts, are caused by certain types of the human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV types 6 and 11.

 

Option B. Sexually transmitted This is true as well. HPV, which causes condylomata acuminata, is transmitted through sexual contact.

 

Option D. Occurs in genitalia This statement is true. Condylomata acuminata typically appear in the moist mucocutaneous regions of the genitalia and are characterized by their cauliflower-like appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condylomata acuminata are benign lesions caused by HPV and are sexually transmitted. They typically appear in the genitalia and, while they may persist or recur, they rarely progress to malignancy.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 970
